trans-unit.source: Manage Service Bus with PowerShell
trans-unit.target: Manage Service Bus with PowerShell

trans-unit.source: Manage Service Bus with PowerShell scripts instead of .NET
trans-unit.target: Manage Service Bus with PowerShell scripts instead of .NET

trans-unit.source: Microsoft Azure PowerShell is a scripting environment that you can use to control and automate the deployment and management of your workloads in Azure.
trans-unit.target: Microsoft Azure PowerShell is a scripting environment that you can use to control and automate the deployment and management of your workloads in Azure.

trans-unit.source: This article describes how to use PowerShell to provision and manage Service Bus entities such as namespaces, queues, and Event Hubs using a local Azure PowerShell console.
trans-unit.target: This article describes how to use PowerShell to provision and manage Service Bus entities such as namespaces, queues, and Event Hubs using a local Azure PowerShell console.

trans-unit.source: Before you begin this article, you must have the following:
trans-unit.target: Before you begin this article, you must have the following:

trans-unit.source: An Azure subscription.
trans-unit.target: An Azure subscription.

trans-unit.source: Azure is a subscription-based platform.
trans-unit.target: Azure is a subscription-based platform.

trans-unit.source: For more information about obtaining a subscription, see [Purchase Options], [Member Offers], or [Free Trial].
trans-unit.target: For more information about obtaining a subscription, see [Purchase Options], [Member Offers], or [Free Trial].

trans-unit.source: A computer with Azure PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: A computer with Azure PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: For instructions, see [Install and configure Azure PowerShell].
trans-unit.target: For instructions, see [Install and configure Azure PowerShell].

trans-unit.source: A general understanding of PowerShell scripts, NuGet packages, and the .NET Framework.
trans-unit.target: A general understanding of PowerShell scripts, NuGet packages, and the .NET Framework.

trans-unit.source: There are a limited number of PowerShell cmdlets available for managing Service Bus.
trans-unit.target: There are a limited number of PowerShell cmdlets available for managing Service Bus.

trans-unit.source: To provision entities that are not exposed through the existing cmdlets, you can use the .NET client for Service Bus in the [Service Bus NuGet package].
trans-unit.target: To provision entities that are not exposed through the existing cmdlets, you can use the .NET client for Service Bus in the [Service Bus NuGet package].

trans-unit.source: First, make sure that the script can locate the Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll assembly, which is installed with the NuGet package.
trans-unit.target: First, make sure that the script can locate the Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll assembly, which is installed with the NuGet package.

trans-unit.source: In order to be flexible, the script performs these steps:
trans-unit.target: In order to be flexible, the script performs these steps:

trans-unit.source: Determines the path at which it was invoked.
trans-unit.target: Determines the path at which it was invoked.

trans-unit.source: Traverses the path until it finds a folder named packages.
trans-unit.target: Traverses the path until it finds a folder named packages.

trans-unit.source: This folder is created when you install NuGet packages.
trans-unit.target: This folder is created when you install NuGet packages.

trans-unit.source: Recursively searches the packages folder for an assembly named Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll.
trans-unit.target: Recursively searches the packages folder for an assembly named Microsoft.ServiceBus.dll.

trans-unit.source: References the assembly so that the types are available for later use.
trans-unit.target: References the assembly so that the types are available for later use.

trans-unit.source: Here's how these steps are implemented in a PowerShell script:
trans-unit.target: Here's how these steps are implemented in a PowerShell script:

trans-unit.source: Two PowerShell cmdlets support Service Bus namespace operations.
trans-unit.target: Two PowerShell cmdlets support Service Bus namespace operations.

trans-unit.source: Instead of the .NET SDK APIs, you can use [Get-AzureSBNamespace] and [New-AzureSBNamespace].
trans-unit.target: Instead of the .NET SDK APIs, you can use [Get-AzureSBNamespace] and [New-AzureSBNamespace].

trans-unit.source: This example creates a few local variables in the script; $Namespace and $Location.
trans-unit.target: This example creates a few local variables in the script; $Namespace and $Location.

trans-unit.source: $Namespace is the name the of the Service Bus namespace with which we want to work.
trans-unit.target: $Namespace is the name the of the Service Bus namespace with which we want to work.

trans-unit.source: $Location identifies the data center in which the script provisions the namespace.
trans-unit.target: $Location identifies the data center in which the script provisions the namespace.

trans-unit.source: $CurrentNamespace stores the reference namespace that the script retrieves (or creates).
trans-unit.target: $CurrentNamespace stores the reference namespace that the script retrieves (or creates).

trans-unit.source: In an actual script, $Namespace and $Location can be passed as parameters.
trans-unit.target: In an actual script, $Namespace and $Location can be passed as parameters.

trans-unit.source: This part of the script does the following:
trans-unit.target: This part of the script does the following:

trans-unit.source: Attempts to retrieve a Service Bus namespace with the provided name.
trans-unit.target: Attempts to retrieve a Service Bus namespace with the provided name.

trans-unit.source: If the namespace is found, it reports what was found.
trans-unit.target: If the namespace is found, it reports what was found.

trans-unit.source: If the namespace is not found, it creates the namespace and then retrieves the newly created namespace.
trans-unit.target: If the namespace is not found, it creates the namespace and then retrieves the newly created namespace.

trans-unit.source: To provision other Service Bus entities, create an instance of the NamespaceManager class from the SDK.
trans-unit.target: To provision other Service Bus entities, create an instance of the NamespaceManager class from the SDK.

trans-unit.source: You can use the [Get-AzureSBAuthorizationRule] cmdlet to retrieve an authorization rule that's used to provide a connection string.
trans-unit.target: You can use the [Get-AzureSBAuthorizationRule] cmdlet to retrieve an authorization rule that's used to provide a connection string.

trans-unit.source: We'll store a reference to the NamespaceManager instance in the $NamespaceManager variable.
trans-unit.target: We'll store a reference to the NamespaceManager instance in the $NamespaceManager variable.

trans-unit.source: We will use $NamespaceManager later in the script to provision other entities.
trans-unit.target: We will use $NamespaceManager later in the script to provision other entities.

trans-unit.source: In order to provision other entities, such as queues, topics, and Event Hubs, use the [.NET API for Service Bus].
trans-unit.target: In order to provision other entities, such as queues, topics, and Event Hubs, use the [.NET API for Service Bus].

trans-unit.source: This article focuses only on Event Hubs, but the steps for other entities are similar.
trans-unit.target: This article focuses only on Event Hubs, but the steps for other entities are similar.

trans-unit.source: In addition, more detailed examples, including other entities, are referenced at the end of this article.
trans-unit.target: In addition, more detailed examples, including other entities, are referenced at the end of this article.

trans-unit.source: This part of the script creates four more local variables.
trans-unit.target: This part of the script creates four more local variables.

trans-unit.source: These variables are used to instantiate an EventHubDescription object.
trans-unit.target: These variables are used to instantiate an EventHubDescription object.

trans-unit.source: The script does the following:
trans-unit.target: The script does the following:

trans-unit.source: Using the NamespaceManager object, check to see if the Event Hub identified by $Path exists.
trans-unit.target: Using the NamespaceManager object, check to see if the Event Hub identified by $Path exists.

trans-unit.source: If it does not exist, create an EventHubDescription and pass that to the NamespaceManager class CreateEventHubIfNotExists method.
trans-unit.target: If it does not exist, create an EventHubDescription and pass that to the NamespaceManager class CreateEventHubIfNotExists method.

trans-unit.source: After determining that the Event Hub is available, create a consumer group using ConsumerGroupDescription and NamespaceManager.
trans-unit.target: After determining that the Event Hub is available, create a consumer group using ConsumerGroupDescription and NamespaceManager.

trans-unit.source: This article provided a basic outline for provisioning Service Bus entities using PowerShell.
trans-unit.target: This article provided a basic outline for provisioning Service Bus entities using PowerShell.

trans-unit.source: Anything that you can do using the .NET client libraries, you can also do in a PowerShell script.
trans-unit.target: Anything that you can do using the .NET client libraries, you can also do in a PowerShell script.

trans-unit.source: There are more detailed examples available on these blogs posts:
trans-unit.target: There are more detailed examples available on these blogs posts:

trans-unit.target: <linkText>How to create Service Bus queues, topics and subscriptions using a PowerShell script</linkText><title></title>

trans-unit.target: Some ready-made scripts are also available for download:
